speakers.name: kasiasun
speakers.description: PM at GitHub

title: Product Management with GitHub
description: The presentation will focus on best practices for product managers, prioritization, shipping small and incremental features, and utilizing GitHub features for planning and tracking your work.

speakers.name: Hilmar Maximilian Orth
speakers.description:
Hilmar is the Founder of Gelato, web3‚Äôs automation protocol, which is the leading decentralized infrastructure network used by projects such as MakerDAO, Olympus, Connext and Pancake Swap to automate their smart contract processes across 9 EVM chains.

Coming from a background in finance, Hilmar has been working & building products on Ethereum for the past 6 years.

title: How we killed the "Network Switch" dropdown
description:
Haven't you been there yourself? You have two dapps open at the same time, one which tries to connect you to Ethereum and the other one to Optimism, resulting in an infinite  "Please switch your network" loop. 

In order to abstract away & finally "kill" the Network Switch dropdown that we all hate, we have to overcome to issues: 1) Cross-chain Gas Payments & 2) "Soft" Account abstraction. 

In this talk we will explore how we at Gelato killed the "Network Switch" and how you can do the same

speakers.name: Kevin Owocki
speakers.description: Kevin Owocki is the founder of Gitcoin.co ‚Äî Where builders & funders come together to build the open web.  Gitcoin has delivered $60mm worth of value to OSS devs in the last several years. He has a BS in Computer Science, 15 years of engineering leadership experience in Open Source Software and Web Startups. Kevin is a community organizer in the Boulder Colorado Tech Scene.

title: How Crypto Can Regenerate the World ü§ñ‚ù§Ô∏èüåéüå±
description: This talk is about cryptoeconomic systems that create positive externalities for their neighbors & for the world.  In this talk, I plan to explore the intersection of programmable money, game theory, & mechanism design. I will provide updates on ImpactDAOs - the design space that is searching for powerful new ways to to fund, design, develop, & market regenerative web3-era applications and digital assets. Together, we launch the meme of regenerative crypto-economics into the world.

speakers.name: Kevin Owocki
speakers.description: Kevin Owocki is the founder of Gitcoin.co ‚Äî Where builders & funders come together to build the open web.  Gitcoin has delivered $60mm worth of value to OSS devs in the last several years. He has a BS in Computer Science, 15 years of engineering leadership experience in Open Source Software and Web Startups. Kevin is a community organizer in the Boulder Colorado Tech Scene.

title: 1 Human 1 Vote Money Legos üîú More Democratic DAOs üß±ü§ù‚ú®
description:
Right now, the DAO ecosystem is built around one-token-one-vote or one-cpu-one-vote schemes.

With strong sybil resistence, the ecosystem could move to DAOs built on one-human-one-vote. This unlocks more democratic use cases like:

- quadratic funding
- quadratic voting
- Gini coefficient measurements
- UBI
- one-person-one-vote DAOs
- data collectives
- sybil resistant airdrops
+ more

Learn about the current landscape of sybil resistance techniques in web3.

speakers.name: Lefteris Karapetsas
speakers.description:
ethereum developer since 2014! Contributed to solidity compiler and c++ ethereum.
Built the DAO, saw it get destroyed, then hacked it back to save whatever we could both in ETH and ETC.
Development lead for the Raiden network.
Founder of rotki.

I like birding :D

speakers.name: Konstantinos Paparas
speakers.description: Open-source software developer

title: rotki: Why it‚Äôs open source and local-first and why should you care?
description:
This will be a talk on the why we need opensource, local-first privacy preserving tools in this field. 

Reiterate the benefits of opensource and the cypherphunk ethos that built the crypto field. Ponder why so many people still develop closed source centralized tools and explain why this is contrary to the core ethos of the field.

Then by using rotki as a main example show how things can and should be done differently. The opensource, local-first way.

Explore both benefits and drawbacks

speakers.name: Kevin Owocki
speakers.description: Kevin Owocki is the founder of Gitcoin.co ‚Äî Where builders & funders come together to build the open web.  Gitcoin has delivered $60mm worth of value to OSS devs in the last several years. He has a BS in Computer Science, 15 years of engineering leadership experience in Open Source Software and Web Startups. Kevin is a community organizer in the Boulder Colorado Tech Scene.

title: Quadratic Funding - a money lego for Impact üß±üìàüå±

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description:
Quadratic Funding is an idea from Vitalik Buterin, Glen Weyl, and Zoe Hitzig.

During a QF round, a matching pool is raised, and then a crowdfund campaign is matched according to the QF algorithm:
1. No of contributors matters more than amount funded.
2. This pushes power to the edges, away from whales & other central power brokers.
3. This creates more democracy in public goods funding decisions! ü¶Ñ

In this talk by Gitcoin Grants founder Kevin Owocki, we will learn about this money lego.

speakers.name: Nathan
speakers.description: Business Development contributor with DXdao

title: Product Ownership in DeFi
description: https://twitter.com/DXdao_/status/1496877586856783875

speakers.name: Tarun Chitra
speakers.description: Floating through the Ether, reading math papers, writing DeFi research @GauntletNetwork, techno lover.

title: Cost of Feudalism: Towards a Theory of MEV
description: Maximal Extractable Value (MEV) is excess value captured by miners/validator. This excess value often comes from reordering, censoring, or inserting new transactions that allow a miner to front-run users' transactions. Is MEV *always* bad? Can it sometimes lead to good equilibria for users? We modify tools from algorithmic game theory and probability to prove some surprising paradoxes ‚Äî *some* MEV improves trading efficiency in networks of automated market makers.

speakers.name: Hudson Jameson
speakers.description: Hudson is a long time Ethereum contributor having previously worked in the Ethereum Foundation for 5 years on numerous efforts including protocol dev coordination, specifications, and co-running Devcon2-4. He co-founded the Ethereum educational and coordination group Ethereum Cat Herders. He has 3 cats and 5 chickens and lives in Texas with his spouse.

title: Mental Health and Avoiding Burnout in Your Crypto Gig
description: Ethereum culture is 24/7 and always on. This brings with it a lot of challenges for DAOs and crypto orgs who need to balance growth and fast paced crypto culture with mental health. Without the proper knowledge and steps in place burnout can run rampant in a team. This talk discusses some of the things to watch out for, how teammates can be accountable for each other, and how to strive for a work/life balance.

speakers.name: Graham McBain
speakers.description: Graham McBain loves meme, people, and decentralization.

title: Bring web3 to people, not people into web3
description:
Often we talk about how to "bring more people into web3", but I believe this is wrong. We need to bring web3 to people where they already are. In this talk I'll share how Ethereum can do a better job of adding value to people's lives without making them get lessons in economics, game theory & cryptography. 

I'll share a vision for how Ethereum can work to target their audience on platforms beyond twitter. Most importantly I'll share why it's important to branch out for us to grow.

speakers.name: Graham McBain
speakers.description: Graham McBain loves meme, people, and decentralization.

title: Bring web3 to people, not people into web3
description:
Often we talk about how to "bring more people into web3", but I believe this is wrong. We need to bring web3 to people where they already are. In this talk I'll share how Ethereum can do a better job of adding value to people's lives without making them get lessons in economics, game theory & cryptography. 

I'll share a vision for how Ethereum can work to target their audience on platforms beyond twitter. Most importantly I'll share why it's important to branch out for us to grow.

speakers.name: Franz
speakers.description:
Research:
- University of Hamburg

Awards:
- EthAmsterdam
- Hack Money

title: MEV NFT: ERC-721 fork for blocking atomic arbitrage

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description:
Inspiration
MEV (miner extractable value) is an issue that often times disbenefits the smaller consumers or traders. While traditional MEV research is mostly focussed on sandwich trades, we focus on one specific type of extractable value: MEV NFT!

Let's illuminate the dark forest.

In the talk we present a novel way to analyse and detect NFT arbitrage for more transparency. With that research we design a ERC-721 token that blocks malicious bots and could benefit consumers.

speakers.name: Julian Traversa
speakers.description:
Founder @ Swivel

DeFi @ Gitcoin Kernel & Steward @ Gitcoin DAO

MOBA Degenerate, Contributor/Author of EIP-4626, EIP-5095

title: Amplifying Consensus Participation with Blockspace Markets
description:
In order to maximize staking participation post-merge, we need to provide capital markets for blockspace demand.

This can come in the form of Yield Tokenization (e.g. Swivel, Element), blockspace reservations (e.g. Eden Network), or direct exchanges (e.g. Alkimiya), however composable infrastructure is necessary.

With composable infrastructure on the capital markets layer, we can create interesting instruments such as combined staking+lending+options products, and derivative stablecoins.

speakers.name: Lenny Johnson
speakers.description: Lenny Johnson is a content creator, community lead at Web3lagos and product designer at Finance.vote

title: Solving Society's Greatest Challenges With Web3
description:
How the greatest challenges we face as a society can be solved using web3 technology.

Poverty, Corruption, Environmental degradation...my talk focuses on how web3 has already created the tools to solve these challenges.

All that's required now is ambitious implementation with the goal of creating a more perfect world.

speakers.name: DenisDevcic
speakers.description:
Working as a product manager in Communication league of Idle Finance, a yield aggregator DeFi protocol, he's experienced what it means to be working in a DAO.
To counterbalance the web 3.0 field of interest, he's also the owner of a physical store located in Zagreb, specializing in trading card games & board games. In an attempt to have a work-life balance, he's into rock climbing, reading and traveling.
Denis has been shaped by a dynamic marketing agency experience.

title: Why you should work in a DAO
description:
The journey into the web3:
What I wish I knew when I started working in a DAO, and how to get the most out of that experience for yourself & for your DAO.
The talk goes through the 7 challenges and lessons I learned in my experience when working for a DAO. Something that will be useful for anybody thinking about joining a DAO.

speakers.name: sandusky
speakers.description:
Self taught Programmer, artist and cultural promoter.
Subgraph developer for Protofire.io 
Blockchain consultant for Platohedro.org
7+ years working with arts, culture and communities.
3+ years building software solutions.

title: Using blockchain to overcome LATAM challenges
description:
Latam has a very complex background facing issues such as govt corruption, inequality, lack of opportunities, violence and so on... 
Many of these problems have been discussed for a while always from centralized points of view. 
In this talk we will explore 5 escenarios where Blockchain technology can improve quality of life for latam people.

speakers.name: Diego Mazo
speakers.description: Cofounder of Tropykus finance.  Ethereum foundation 2x grantee with Descubriendo Blockchain educational program. Ethereum scholar in Devcon V Osaka Japan.

title: Understanding Latinamericans to design a local flavour DeFi platform
description: From El Salvador to Argentina, passing through Colombia, we applied local UX research iteratively with our own methodology TUD "Tropykal User Dive"  to define specific financial needs across different countries in Latam. This process has helped us to define a DeFi product designed for the needs of Latinamericans and with a highlighted local flavour. We would like to share our method openly to be replicated in other emerging economies around the world.

speakers.name: Bobby Bola
speakers.description: Governance @ StableNode | Medical Student

title: Delegates and Streamlined Governance
description: In this talk, we are going to explore some of the common issues in decentralized governance and understand how delegates can tackle them.

speakers.name: cryptowanderer
speakers.description: Lover

title: Care-full Communities of Learning

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description:
[Kernel](https://kernel.community) has been running an open educational web for more than two years. We have developed a set of patterns and tools to free learning and have implemented them throughout six "blocks" or fellowships.
Coordination, the management of shared resources, and positive-sum decision making all require both common knowledge and diverse understandings. This seeming paradox can only be held meaningfully in ongoing, honest, humble conversation: which is how we learn together.

speakers.name: Marius van der Wijden
speakers.description: Marius joined the Ethereum Foundation in 2020 to work on go-ethereum. He's interested in fuzzing, testing and shipping The Merge. He wrote his master thesis on differential fuzzing of EVMs where he found 3 critical consensus issues.

title: Killing ETH - Finding Consensus Issues on Layer 1
description:
Ethereum's core protocol is highly security critical and thus needs to be tested thoroughly. This talk will discuss the testing methods we use to make sure that all execution layer clients implement the same protocol:
- Regression testing on hive
- EVM-fuzzing
- Devnets
- Shadow forks
We will discuss a bunch of interesting issues that we found with that

speakers.name: Aliasgar Merchant
speakers.description:
Aliasgar is the Founder of Cosmos Antimatter a validator network that advocates the Decentralization of Blockchain. He is also the Co-Founder of Learn Web3 With Us an education initiative to make Web3 education mainstream. 

Aliasgar also works as a Senior Developer Relations Engineer at Ignite (Formerly Tendermint).

title: Decentralization within Blockchain Ecosystem
description:
Blockchain is often described as Distributed and shared network. Blockchain was designed to be always Decentralized where no single person or entity controls the network. However, what happens when a cartel of validators gets the majority of the shares of a network; such that they can control the entire network.

This talk will be focused on how Blockchain technology can be made truly decentralized.

speakers.name: Uri Kirstein
speakers.description: Uri is a Developer Advocate and Software Developer at Certora. Uri fell in love with blockchain in 2018 after doing a research project as an undergraduate student at the Technion. He joined Certora right after graduation.

title: Bad proofs in Formal Verification
description: Formal verification can be a huge boon to smart contract security as it checks all possible execution paths. Unfortunately, even verified code can be faulty if the formal specification contains mistakes. "Bad" proofs can lead to false confidence in the code and premature deployment. This talk will discuss different types of "bad" proofs and how to avoid them.

speakers.name: Rostyslav Bortman
speakers.description:
Currently, I am the Head of the Blockchain Department at IdeaSoft (member of Sigma Software Group). We have a team of Ethereum/Solidity devs, we successfully deliver different blockchain projects.
Also, I am a lecturer at Sigma Software University - solidity courses.

https://university.sigma.software/trainers/rostislav-bortman/
https://www.linkedin.com/in/rostyslav-bortman-188622111/

Also, I created Kyiv Ethereum Community - https://www.facebook.com/kyivetherem (wrote about it before)

title: How to setup an ideal dev environment with Hardhat

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description: Hardhat is a great tool for solidity developers which helps to maintain and test your codebase. However, it has some areas to improve, for example, Etherscan verification which is not automated by default. On the workshop, we will walk through all such cases and will create the most comfortable dev environment you could even imagine.

title: Fossil Workshop
description: Fossil is a set of smart contracts on both Starknet and Ethereum L1 that allow Starknet smart contracts to read anything ever committed to Ethereum L1 and any of it‚Äôs EVM based L2s.

speakers.name: Santiago Siri
speakers.description: Founder of Democracy Earth Foundation, a non-profit organization backed by Y Combinator that has built Universal Basic Income on Ethereum and launched the Proof of Humanity protocol. In the past he started the Partido de la Red, the first political party born out of the Internet that ran for elections in Argentina. Author of "Hacktivismo", published in 2015 by Random House.

title: Universal Basic Income for Humanity
description: On 2021 the Proof of Humanity protocol was released alongside the UBI token reaching almost 20k humans receiving Universal Basic Income. This talk will offer direct testimonials from users on how UBI has impacted their lives. We will demo how Proof of Humanity v2 will support the use of Soul Bound Tokens and reduce costs using Layer 2. Also we will explain how UBI v2 extends its streaming features allowing real time money and how we can create regenerative economics for it as a community.

speakers.name: Ernesto Garc√≠a
speakers.description: Fullstack Ethereum Developer @ OpenZeppelin

title: Monitoring and Operating a DAO using OpenZeppelin Defender
description:
OpenZeppelin Defender is a tool I work on, and it's used by several protocols to monitor and operate smart contract infrastructure that has many use cases for protocols and DAOs.

This talk is a general overview of how to use Defender to control operations over the smart contracts of a DAO, explaining how to architecture these Smart Contracts and use the tooling that's built on the platform to control proposals, create timelocks, execute upgrades, and some other examples.

speakers.name: Connor Spelliscy
speakers.description:
Run the DAO Research Collective, which accelerates DAO functionality by procuring and open sourcing targeted research foundational to effective DAO operation. We‚Äôve received grants from the Ethereum Foundation, Uniswap, Compound, and Aave for our work.

Co-founded the Blockchain Association and the Canadian Web3 Council, two of the leading industry associations for crypto, focused on building better regulatory outcomes for the industry.

title: Open Sourcing and Coordinating DAO Research for the Public Good
description:
DAOs are cutting-edge organizational structures and there is limited precedent to help DAO stakeholders understand how to operate. DAOs are now starting to research legal, governance, treasury management, tax, and other issues, but much of the foundational learnings of DAO stakeholders are siloed within their own communities.

My talk would focus on how we as a community coordinate, procure, and open-source research foundational to DAO operations to more effectively scale the industry.

speakers.name: Alessio
speakers.description:
Alessio founded the international tech accelerator Aurelia Ventures and he covered the position of ChGrowth Officer. He was responsible for the web 3.0 vertical in the accelerator, supporting startups in the transition from web 2.0 to web 3.0, token design, networking, fundraising, etc. 
Alessio has been consulting companies in web 3.0 since 2017, in fact, he collaborated with organizations like Paxful, Novem Gold, Cartesi, and many others. 
In 2016 Alessio began study

title: Let's Decentralise the Accelerator! The necessity of building an Accelerator DAO to support web 3.0 startups.
description:
I have founded and supported the growth of an international accelerator for tech startups called Aurelia Ventures. 
After 5 years and 104 startups, something was missing. Not the revenue, not the emotions but the Philosophy and the Ethos.
We need to redesign accelerators for web 3.0 startups as DAOs. We redistribute governance, ownership, and financial upside. With this super-inclusive system, we can help web 3.0 builders that want to create a more equitable digital space.

speakers.name: Germ√°n K√ºber
