speakers.description: Author, teacher, software engineer.

title: Scaling Web3
description:
Like Bitcoin & Ethereum introduced new paradigms for building decentralized applications, we‚Äôre now seeing another shift in how blockchain networks are architected, moving away from monolithic architectures to a modular approach that decouples the various layers like consensus, execution, data availability, & settlement

In this talk, I‚Äôll explain the benefits of building in this way, why the industry is headed towards this direction, and highlight 7 properties of the modular blockchain stack

speakers.name: Julian
speakers.description: Researcher Developer in the Research and Innovation group at IOV Labs. He has a Computer Science MSC degree from the University of Buenos Aires in 2022. Currently, he's doing research on blockchain about scalability.

title: Parallel Transaction Execution
description: We present a new method to increase throughput using parallel transaction processing without modifying the block gas limit. The parallelization algorithm is simple to implement and relies on block proposers specifying a schedule of execution. We demonstrate the effectiveness by processing synthetic blocks drawn from Ethereum's distribution of transactions.

speakers.name: Janice Taylor
speakers.description: 3X founder, Built early products in digital animation and children's digital safety across 5 major sports league, Creator of healing modality Ahava as it pertains to financial wellness, Founder of EQ exchange, first all women led team in the Music NFT finance space. Author, Award Winner, Oprah Top 150.

title: Solving Financial Inequality In Music
description: The underpinnings of the current financial system (web2) was built with inherent bias towards women and people of colour. The promise of Web3 and the brilliant innovation of Ethereum allows for the first time in history where financial inequality can be addressed. The tools that have and have not been created today in the future hold the promise to solve this inequality. Music and creative endeavours are the great equalizer across all societies. Music is the universal language of Web3.

speakers.name: Florian Glatz
speakers.description:
Trained as a lawyer and software developer with many years of experience working full-time in the blockchain space, Florian is aware of the key issues at the intersection of crypto assets and regulation.

Florian Glatz has co-founded and led the German Blockchain Association (Bundesblock) as President for its first four years. He advises political decision-makers at the German and European level on blockchain regulation.

title: Founder Clinic: Get a checkup on your Legal Exposure as a buidler in crypto/web3
description: The founder clinic is a place where web3 builders can come and anonymously discuss their fears and concerns related to legal issues connected to what they're building in web3. both existing and upcoming regulation in US and Europe, founders stand to be exposed to significant legal risk. An honest heart to heart in a safe space can go a long way to give someone the confidence to continue on their path, while mitigating risks effectively.

speakers.name: Nima
speakers.description: Head of Growth @ Solace - a DeFi Insurance DApp. Trader, Researcher, Writer. Love all things DeFi, NFTs, and Infra.

title: The DeFi Insurance Problem - An Analysis of the Failures, Successes, and Potential of the Nascent Industry
description:
Why is it that despite many teams making attempts to create crypto insurance, none of them have yet succeeded? The reason ‚Äî the fundamental problem paralyzing DeFi Insurance‚Äôs growth and success is the lack of underwriting capital.

In the talk, I will explore the reasons why underwriting is a unique problem in the context of crypto, how current solutions fail to underwrite capital, and how we can potentially approach solving those issues.

speakers.name: Janice Taylor
speakers.description: 3X founder, Built early products in digital animation and children's digital safety across 5 major sports league, Creator of healing modality Ahava as it pertains to financial wellness, Founder of EQ exchange, first all women led team in the Music NFT finance space. Author, Award Winner, Oprah Top 150.

title: Solving Financial Inequality In Music
description: The underpinnings of the current financial system (web2) was built with inherent bias towards women and people of colour. The promise of Web3 and the brilliant innovation of Ethereum allows for the first time in history where financial inequality can be addressed. The tools that have and have not been created today in the future hold the promise to solve this inequality. Music and creative endeavours are the great equalizer across all societies. Music is the universal language of Web3.

speakers.name: Daniel Zachary Goldman
speakers.description: Techie @ Arbitrum

title: Understanding L2: Ordering and Execution (aka Everything You've Always Wanted to Know About Sequencers But Were Afraid To Ask)
description: Overview of design patterns in handling ordering and execution; will cover separation of roles between sequencers and validators, tradeoffs in different ways handing execution & ordering, current approaches ‚Äî i.e., what various L2 rollups are doing in production, what is and isn't possible in principle.

speakers.name: Jorik
speakers.description:
Jorik has a background in compilers, type theory and networking.
They are a cairo-lang experts working at Nethermind. They have contributed to Warp - a Solidity to Cairo transpiler - and the AAVE to Starknet port.
In the process he's had to teach himself zkStarks

title: Warp - Insights into Solidity and Cairo
description:
Warp is a Solidity to Cairo compiler. Its intent is to seamlessly deploy Solidity contracts onto StarkNet. Warp is an intricate tool whose implementation sheds light the design choices of Solidity and Cairo.

Join this talk for a deep dive on the compiler architecture, a breakdown of the most interesting passes and a discussion of language design choices in the L1 and L2 space.

speakers.name: Grigore Ro»ôu
speakers.description: Grigore Ro»ôu is the founder and CEO of Runtime Verification and a Computer Science professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, where he leads the Formal Systems Laboratory. Previously, he was a scientist at NASA, where he coined the term runtime verification with his colleagues. He is interested in programming languages, formal methods, and software engineering, and especially in how to combine these to increase the safety, security, and dependability of computing systems.

title: Trustworthy Formal Verification for Ethereum Smart Contracts via Proof Certificates and ZK-Proofs
description: In this talk, it will be explained how to make blockchain applications and smart contracts more trustworthy by generating rigorous, complete, and machine-checkable proof certificates, in the context of the K framework. Further, we will discuss how to use ZK-proofs to verify/compress the checking of those proof certificates.

speakers.name: Harry Kalodner
speakers.description: Harry Kalodner is Co-Founder and Chief Technology Officer at Offchain Labs where he leads the engineering team. Before the company he attended Princeton as a PhD candidate where his research explored economics, anonymity, and incentive compatibility of cryptocurrencies. When not up at 3:00am writing code, Harry occasionally sleeps.

title: On the Path to a Rollup-Centric Future
description: It‚Äôs only been slightly over a year since Arbitrum launched as the first optimistic rollup that supported general EVM contract deployment. In that time many components have shifted, many users have migrated, and an entirely new generation of technology has shipped with Nitro. Now we look towards tackling the next set of challenges in working towards Ethereum‚Äôs rollup centric future, where using Ethereum will mean using a rollup.

speakers.name: Matt Pearring
speakers.description: Matt leads Developer Relations at Arbitrum. Originally from the Big Island of Hawaii, he enjoys music, video games, and the daily coffee ritual.

title: Ups and Downs: Onboarding a million users to Layer-2
description: In the last year we‚Äôve seen thousands of projects and billions of dollars migrate over to rollups. Liquidity and users have started aggressively migrating, but there‚Äôs still a long way to go. In this talk we‚Äôll cover successful use cases, pain points that make it challenging for both users and developers to onboard, and emerging projects and protocols in the layer 2 space that are showing a lot of promise.

speakers.name: Joao Reginatto
speakers.description: Joao Reginatto is VP Product at Circle, where he leads stablecoin product initiatives. Joao has over 20 years experience in the tech industry, leading product and engineering teams across the US, Europe and Latin America. He is passionate about building more open financial services platforms and products for businesses and consumers around the world. He holds an MBA from EMLYON Business School in France and a Bachelor in Computer Science from UFRGS in Brazil.

title: Reliable Bridging of Off-chain Collateralized Stablecoins
description: In this talk we will talk about the bridging of off-chain collateralized Ethereum stablecoins and how those differ from the bridging of other native Ethereum assets. We will discuss the inherent centralization aspect of off-chain collateralized stablecoins built on Ethereum, and how that aspect can be leveraged for the design of a more reliable and secure bridging approach based on burn-and-mint model, rather than an escrow-and-mint model

speakers.name: Daniel Zachary Goldman
speakers.description: Techie @ Arbitrum

title: Building a Layer-2 NFT Bridge
description: Cross-chain communication is one of the most complex and interesting parts of multi-chain development. In this workshop we‚Äôll build out an NFT bridge from the ground up between Ethereum and Arbitrum covering all you need to know about bridging design and cross chain messaging. You‚Äôll walk out with a set of smart contracts you can use to bridge your mainnet NFT collection along with way more than you ever wanted to know about bridging.

speakers.name: Eddie Penta
speakers.description: Full stack developer who also makes games and developer utilities.

title: Extendable Universal Token
description: The Universal Token is a smart-contract framework for creating customisable tokens. Tokens created following the framework are composed of a Token contract to which one or multiple Extension contracts can be connected. Using the Universal Token API, developers can deploy extensions contracts and plug extensions contract to Token contracts, either at token deployment or in real-time on-chain. The Universal Token is compatible with Ethereum‚Äôs most used token standards including ERC20, and ERC721.

speakers.name: Marek Olszewski
speakers.description: Marek is the co-founder and CTO of cLabs, one of the companies contributing to Celo, and President of Valora, an easy-to-use mobile wallet built on Celo. Earlier, he co-founded Locu, a machine learning venture-backed company that was acquired by GoDaddy. He is also an MIT PhD alumni and a former Facebook Fellow and has previously worked at Google, Microsoft Research, and Sun Labs.

title: How we onboard a billion people into web3
description:
To onboard billions of people into crypto, we must make it exceedingly easy for them to on ramp (in every country in the world) into a self custodial wallet and get transacting without taking on currency risk. To get there, we need:

- A standardized api for on/off ramps (e.g. the WalletConnect of on/off ramps - FiatConnect)
- Stablecoins for every fiat currency in the world
- Gas payable in stablecoins

This talk will cover various efforts helping us make progress on each of these fronts.

speakers.name: Mehdi Salehi
speakers.description: Integration Engineer @arbitrum

title: Immutability vs. Upgradeability in Ethereum: Myth vs. Reality
description:
This talk investigates the upgradeability of smart contracts on Ethereum and introduces a classification of upgrade patterns. We identify three frameworks to manage upgrades. Furthermore, we propose quantitative analyses of upgrade patterns and control frameworks on the Ethereum mainnet.
This talk also aims to highlight that immutability, as a core property of blockchain, is oversold and show that the widespread use of upgradeability patterns degrades immutability.

speakers.name: Wei Dai
speakers.description: Wei Dai is a Cryptographer at Bain Capital Crypto. He is **not** the inventor of b-money, who the unit of Ethereum and the Maker stablecoin is named after. Nevertheless, he aspires to contribute enough to the R&D of blockchains so that he may one day become "the Wei Dai."

speakers.name: Kyle Charbonnet
speakers.description: Software Security Engineer at the Privacy & Scaling Explorations Team

title: Towards a feature-complete and backwards-compatible Privacy Layer for Ethereum
description: Eth EOAs and token standards (ERC20/721/1155) are terrible for end-user privacy. Can we build an alternative to them that preserves the existing functionalities while providing meaningful anonymity and privacy? This talk explores the functionality requirements of Eth user accounts, such as asset use authorization, asset & identity provenance, what privacy means in the areas of DeFi, NFTs, and identity, as well as concrete ways to build such an ecosystem.

speakers.name: Tyrone Lobban
speakers.description: Tyrone leads J.P. Morgan‚Äôs Blockchain & Crypto team and is responsible for creating innovative Web3-focused products & solutions for J.P. Morgan‚Äôs businesses and clients, and for engaging with the industry at large in order to provide a holistic blockchain strategy for the firm. Tyrone is also the Head of Onyx Digital Assets, a multi-asset tokenization platform that enables the exchange of value for various types of digital assets. Tyrone was previously Head of Product for Quorum, an open-source

title: Inside the Token Factory: how a trillion dollars of traditional assets is moving to blockchain

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description: Learn how some of the world‚Äôs largest financial institutions have combined Ethereum Standards, traditional tech infrastructure and legal precedent to bring global financial assets on to blockchain, and how this could ultimately unlock a new wave of DeFi. We focus on specific implementation details and lessons learned along the way in.

speakers.name: Jorik
speakers.description:
Jorik has a background in compilers, type theory and networking.
They are a cairo-lang experts working at Nethermind. They have contributed to Warp - a Solidity to Cairo transpiler - and the AAVE to Starknet port.
In the process he's had to teach himself zkStarks

speakers.name: Swapnil
speakers.description:
Swapnil has a background in compilers and type theory.
They are a cairo-lang expert working at Nethermind. They have contributed to Warp - a Solidity to Cairo transpiler - and the AAVE to Starknet port.

title: Lay man's ZK
description:
This talk will cover the workings of zero-knowledge Starks. We will discuss the mathematics involved in generating and verifying a zero knowledge proof. The talk also discusses various applications of ZK.

If you know some Linear Algebra come. This talk is intended for curious engineers and not math PhDs.

speakers.name: Martin
speakers.description: Martin K√∂ppelmann has been an entrepreneur in the blockchain space for more than 8 years. He is the Co-Founder of Gnosis, which has contributed leading infrastructure to the industry, including the Gnosis Safe, CoW protocol and is now working on Gnosis Chain. Martin has also founded CirclesUBI - a project to establish a global UBI via a cryptocurrency.

title: Circles UBI - resilient money
description:
CirclesUBI aims to introduce a new cryptocurrency based on the concept of universal basic income. It relies purely on a web of trust mechanisms and specifically does not introduce any central authority or a central authentication mechanism.
Circles has launched with >100k signups in 2020. We are discussing the state of Circles, its usage in different places like Berlin and Bali and are introducing new concepts like "group currencies" as layers on top of Circles as well as non monetary uscases.

speakers.name: Tom Garlick
speakers.description: Tom is the engineering leader on the EY US Blockchain team focused on leading ESG and Sustainability solutions. With over 20 years of technical experience designing and building FinTech and Energy sector solutions, Tom has designed blockchain carbon management systems for emissions tokenization, carbon offsets, and footprint management. He is currently acting Chair of the Carbon Emissions Token (CET) Standards Task Force within the Global Blockchain Business Council (GBBC).

title: Tokenizing Carbon: The path to a lower-carbon future
description: The journey to a lower-carbon future requires companies to take carbon measurement seriously and to publicly tell their decarbonization stories. But, with all stories: you must tell your own or others might tell it for you, and they could get it wrong. Tokenizing carbon for traceability and tying footprints to products gives organizations the ability to publish verifiable emissions, advance net zero ambitions and better manage climate risks with carbon credits. A hero's story the world needs.

speakers.name: Ashley Stanhope
speakers.description: I'm the Director of Communications for Ether Capital, a leading public company focused on staking and building key infrastructure to support the Ethereum ecosystem. Prior to joining Ether Capital, I've spent the past 10 years as a breaking news journalist spearheading coverage for major national and international events. I'm very passionate about crypto, disruptive technologies and programming languages.

title: Devs can BUIDL, But Can They Get Media Attention?
description: Great stories revolve around great characters, something there is no shortage of in the developer community. As someone who spent 10 years as a journalist before pivoting into crypto, I want to help developers tell stories about the products they are building and why they are passionate about what they do. This will not only contribute to brand awareness, but will prove to mainstream media this industry is made up of good people and there's more to report on than just hacks and volatility.

speakers.name: Faris Jebara
speakers.description:
Customer Mgmt. lead with over 15 years experience as an entrepreneur, project manager in p2p operations and cost management consulting. 

Master supply chain and focus in Market research insights and analytics.

title: Partner journey - developer united success
description: For this session the infura success team will be talking about maximizing value via infra, security tooling and developer tooling and how working with partners drives value. More to come soon.

speakers.name: Wei Dai
speakers.description: Wei Dai is a Cryptographer at Bain Capital Crypto. He is **not** the inventor of b-money, who the unit of Ethereum and the Maker stablecoin is named after. Nevertheless, he aspires to contribute enough to the R&D of blockchains so that he may one day become "the Wei Dai."

title: Why we need Threshold FHE for blockchains
description: There is a fundamental limit to building privacy-preserving applications in ZK. For example, we do not know how to replicate applications such as Uniswap and Aave in zero knowledge where complete privacy for users is achieved. This talk introduces how threshold FHE can help fill the gap ZK tech leave us desiring--privacy for shared-state applications.

speakers.name: Yale Vinson
speakers.description: Yale has spent over fifteen years working in the FinTech industry building digital financial services products. Ranging from SIM based payments to tokenized payments, digital gift cards, and peer to peer transactions, he has focused on delivering secure digital financial products that put the needs of consumers first. Most recently, Yale worked on products which enabled crypto for the masses at Diebold Nixdorf and MoneyGram. Yale has a B.S. and an M.S. in Electrical Engineering from Texas A&M.

title: The Role of Monitoring in Your Security Strategy

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description: Monitoring is often seen as a way to merely keep track of important events in the ecosystem in real-time, but in fact it has the potential to provide data analysis, prevent unexpected scenarios where the code behaves unexpectedly, inform users about the current status of a protocol, or even show trends throughout the ecosystem. Join us to understand how to build a monitoring system from scratch to improve the overall security of your protocol.

speakers.name: Anna Stone
speakers.description: Anna Stone is an accomplished Web3 innovator and growth leader with a proven track record in building, launching, and scaling inclusive crypto products, made for the masses, since 2018. She is a co-founder of GoodDollar.org, a social-impact protocol and DAO that leverages free market incentives to pay for building a more equitable world. She has worked in the space of crypto and decentralized finance since 2018, when she led growth for the Bancor Protocol.

title: UBI as a Public Good: Delivering Scalable, Decentralized UBI on Ethereum
description:
Since the inception of Bitcoin, DeFi has been touted as the solution for financial inclusion, but the industry has produced few practical examples of how DeFi is actually supporting the world's 5.5 billion underbanked.

Crypto-based universal basic income systems such as GoodDollar, Proof of Humanity and others provide an antidote to the reality, and present a concrete utility case for DeFi and its ability to onboard the unbanked and soe the seeds of financial empowerment.

speakers.name: ExplorerGeek
speakers.description: Kernel Block 4 Alumni, Building with SurgeWomen, SWE at Solana Foundation, DeveloperDAO #4642

title: Onboarding women to web3
description: I will give a quick intro to myself and how I got into web3. I will then describe the process of writing my first smart contract with Surge Women and the impact our NFT project had to other women in the space. Through this process I have been able to help women in DeveloperDAOWomen and BuildSpaceWomen by providing workshops on gas efficient smart contracts. Being apart of SurgeWomen and building in the space allowed me the opportunity to help other women get into space. We can all pay it forward

speakers.name: cryptowanderer
speakers.description: Lover

speakers.name: Vivek Singh
speakers.description: co-founder at Gitcoin. currently focused on KERNEL, a web3 educational web which brings together 200 incredible peers, 3 times a year for a unique experience. the primary orientation is around deepening generative relationships amongst incredible peers.

title: A More Regenerative, Interactive Commons
description:
"The concept of the commons is not that of a resource; a commons comes from a different way of being in the world where it is not production which counts, but bodily use... established by custom." 

At KERNEL, we've spent 2 years establishing customs which embody regenerative ways of living, both internally and in web3 projects. 

We'd welcome sharing KERNEL customs in an interactive workshop, where we get to know each other & our commons through 4 words: trust, value, freedom, and giving.

speakers.name: Victor
speakers.description: After 2 successful exists became a full-time crypto-analyst from 2016. Developed a proof of stake platform before fully dedicating myself to fighting Sybil and creating a Proof of Personhood based protocol.

title: Approaches to DAO beyond token-weighted voting
description: Token-based voting in protocols and DAOs leads to unpopular decisions in small protocols where large holders are able to make any decision they want. Overview of approaches to balance out token-weighted voting for broader community inclusion, effectiveness and technological implementation in progress which are going to be a reality of tomorrow.

speakers.name: Andrey Falaleev
speakers.description: CTO at Neon Labs (https://neon-labs.org/)

title: Optimistic Parallel Execution on Ethereum Virtual Machine
description:
The speed of transaction processing on EVM is limited by the one-thread model. 
We've implemented an EVM for Solana. The Solana Transaction Processor allows us to run independent contracts in parallel. So, Neon EVM have improvements described in EIP-648.
As a next step, we designed the Optimistic Parallel Execution Architecture to run transaction on the same contract in parallel. And we want to share it with the Ethereum community, because it can be used by other Ethereum-like blockchains.

speakers.name: Dr. Max (Chong) Li
speakers.description: Dr. Max (Chong) Li is an adjunct associate professor in the Electrical Engineering department at Columbia University (in the City of New York), Founder and CEO of Computecoin, Co-founder of Nakamoto and Turing Labs Inc. and Managing Partner of Aves Lair (a seed-stage accelerator based in New York City). Dr. Li holds over 200 patents, and is the inventor of the PoH consensus algorithm. He is a senior member of IEEE and was nominated for the 2019 IEEE Information Theory Society Paper Award. Dr. Li

title: Supporting Web3 applications‚Äô storage and computing needs
description: Two pain points prevent superior cloud services: Web2 infrastructure limits developers with its high cost, lack of privacy and downtime, while nascent web3 infrastructure presents users with a steep learning curve. Computecoin aims to support web3 applications‚Äô storage and computing needs with an accessible, decentralized cloud infrastructure, featuring a DAG network with full Ethereum compatibility, that aggregates and optimizes diverse decentralized clouds to power all-purpose cloud services.

speakers.name: Mathieu
speakers.description: ex MakerDAO, ex Celo

title: Reseed: Leverage proven DeFi primitives for real-world impact
description: tldr: Reseed showcases how DeFi can empower unbanked people by providing access to short term small credits in a decentralized manner. We have built a protocol that incentivizes communities to source microloans, thus automating soem of the most costly part of the business (underwriting and distributing loans). It currently works on a small to medium scale in various communities and we're very excited to scale the protocol over the next coming months, including in Colombia.

speakers.name: Mike Connor
speakers.description: Mike Connor is an applied cryptographer at Aztec Network, the privacy layer for web3. He received his MMath Mathematical Sciences from the University of Bath, and spent three years designing and building tools for private smart contracts on Ethereum.

title: Public-private composability
description:
Learn about the challenges of designing a private execution layer for Ethereum.
Previously, smart contract execution (L1 & L2) has been fully public. Some apps provide basic private functionality for a single private state (e.g. privacy coins).
We'll discuss ways to execute general private and public state changes across multiple smart contracts in one transaction, within a zk-rollup. This unlocks programmable private smart contracts.

speakers.name: Mathieu
speakers.description: ex MakerDAO, ex Celo

title: Reseed: A ReFi protocol for microloans with first traction
description: tldr: Reseed showcases how DeFi can empower unbanked people by providing access to short term small credits in a decentralized manner. We have built a protocol that incentivizes communities to source microloans, thus automating soem of the most costly part of the business (underwriting and distributing loans). It currently works on a small to medium scale in various communities and we're very excited to scale the protocol over the next coming months, including in Colombia.

speakers.name: Bobbin Threadbare
speakers.description: Bobbin is a project lead of Polygon Miden - a STARK-based ZK-rollup being developed at Polygon. Prior to joining Polygon, Bobbin was ZK researcher at Facebook's Novi, where he led the development of Winterfell, as highly-performant general-purpose STARK prover. Besides Winterfell, Bobbin has made multiple contributions to the field of STARK-based proving systems, including a STARK-based virtual machine (Distaff) and AirScript/AirAssembly languages (work supported by the Ethereum Foundation).

title: Generating STARK proofs for arbitrary computations using Miden VM
description: Generating ZK proofs for arbitrary computations has interesting applications in many domains. Unfortunately, this frequently requires a lot of background knowledge or a steep learning curve. In this workshop, we will learn how to write programs for Miden VM - a STARK-based VM which automatically generates STARK-based proofs for any executed program. Miden VM aims to be developer-friendly: it is a regular 32-bit virtual machine with read/write memory and familiar control flow structures.

speakers.name: Krzysztof Urba≈Ñski
speakers.description: Got interested in crypto through The DAO, stayed after its' crash, survived all the cycles. Involved in free software initiatives since the late 90s. Currently system analyst, designer and facilitator + Ethereum advocate in several public discourses.

title: Bridging the mind gap - working with authorities on making blockchain registry legit.
description: In legislation introducing a new kind of company type (simplified joint-stock company), the legislator added a paragraph stating that 'shareholder registry can be kept in a distributed, decentralized database'. I've been working for 5 years with both authorities and institutions to make sure we can have this running on an Ethereum and not some private blockchain. I'd like to share my experiences and conclusions from this work.

speakers.name: Patrick McCorry
speakers.description: Patrick has spent most of his adult life working on cryptocurrencies and his time was split across academic research and industry. Over the years, he has worked on transaction delivery, layer-2 protocols, atomic swaps, consensus protocols, and applied cryptography. Before Infura, he was an Assistant Professor at King‚Äôs College London and an accomplished researcher at UCL, UIUC and NCL.

title: A better mental model Rollups, Plasma, and Validating Bridges
description: Sidechains, Plasma, Rollups, Valdiums, AnyTrust, PoS chains, Crypto Exchanges, all have one thing in common: the bridge. This talk provides an overview on the trust assumptions, threat model, security goals and solutions associated with the humble bridge smart contract. As we will see, rollups emerged because of the scalability bottlenecks faced by Ethereum, but the product-market fit is solving the operational security issues for bridging funds from Ethereum to an off-chain system.

speakers.name: Bianca Buzea
speakers.description: Bianca Buzea is a blockchain technologist with a background in Computer Science. She is passionate about education and web3 development. In the past she has been working at a large web2 company, and recently she joined Balancer Labs as a developer advocate.

title: Avoiding Fragmented Liquidity with the Vault Architecture
description: This lightning talk will provides insights into how to avoid fragmented liquidity using a vault architecture. Additionally, we will look at how the ERC4626-Tokenized Vault Standard can facilitate this architectural design.

speakers.name: Paul Cowgill
speakers.description: Head of Product at Foundation

title: NFT protocol design tradeoffs: Building Foundation OS
description:
Foundation is more than just a website‚Äîit‚Äôs a protocol.

A great protocol needs to balance being simple, reliable, efficient, and flexible. In this talk, I‚Äôll walk through the design space and tradeoffs we made when building the Foundation Protocol. We‚Äôll also discuss how the protocol can be used to build your own record label, high-end auction house, minting site, and much more.

speakers.name: Lana Foglio
speakers.description: Lana is the Communications Manager at Across Protocol, a cross-chain bridge that supports low cost bridging between mainnet and L2s. Some of her specialties include social media strategy, branding and copywriting. Her research done with colleagues from Loyola University Chicago, ‚ÄúIs this Endorsement Authentic? The Effects of Message Sequence in Influencer Marketing,‚Äù is set to be published in in the EAA Advances in Advertising Research Series (Vol. XII) this year.

title: How to Create a Brand Persona That Stands Out in a Sea of Virtual Voices
description: Having an online presence is incredibly important to grow personal and professional brands for yourself online. Unfortunately, in a sea of accounts, many people don‚Äôt have the knowledge to make their brand voice stand out. Their posts may not showcase a distinct personality, there may be too many voices tweeting from the account, or something else altogether. This talk will examine why a brand voice is important and how you can create a brand persona, from conceptualization to finished product.

speakers.name: torchhorse
speakers.description:
~ronseg-hacsym on Urbit
Founding mod of r/NFT (+400k) (2018 - ~)
Oracle

title: ASTROECO ::> The Water Computer
description: A Photoetheric Computing concept for managing wellbeing during lunar cycles scries. Interior Design for computing, and how to start an at home Altar. Celebrating the sweetness that can come from computers and what we can do with token engineering drip systems from token resonance when designing a water-powered computer.

speakers.name: Madalina Raicu
speakers.description: Madalina is a computer scientist who specialized in Human-Computer Interaction. Before getting into Web3, she worked as a software engineer for trading applications in traditional finance and asset management. Nowadays, she works with a decentralized infrastructure that allows anyone to trade and be market makers and collaborates with an NFT marketplace.

title: The UX Psychology of Web3 Exchanges, DeFi vs NFT
description: Despite the existence of numerous dApps,¬†exchanges, and NFT marketplaces, many still perceive exchanges as being risky and uncertain. Others, however, become addicted and feel a range of emotions when they trade, bid, or watch an auction. How can we design¬†for everyone?¬† Due to the underlying nature of Web3, designers take cognitive load constraints into account, while building trust through transparency.

speakers.name: Camilla Abdullina
speakers.description: I am 25 years old from Moscow, Russia. I received a degree in foreign regional studies. Before coming to DeFi I worked as a foreign desk chief at major media for several years, but since being introduced to DeFi, I‚Äôve understood that it is for me! Every day I learn something new and meet innovative people who help and inspire me. Unfortunately, there aren't many women in DeFi, but I think that this situation will improve over time, and I would like to be part of this growth.

speakers.name: Andrew Leonard
speakers.description: Head of Engineering at Solace Finance

title: Security for the Financially Unsecure
description: The most secure entities are large corporations and governments. They often have large reserves and contingency plans in case their crypto gets stolen. But what about the common people? What happens when someone who can only afford to eat rice and beans gets robbed of their last dollar? What can we do to make sure that doesn't happen?

speakers.name: Redwan
speakers.description:
Redwan leads the consulting practice at ChainSafe. He is particularly interested in how Web3 can improve our governance structures and transform the way humans exchange and exist digitally. ChainSafe is a leading multi-chain research and development firm specializing in infrastructure solutions for the decentralized web. 
He gave a talk at Consensus22 and is a keynote speaker at FIL-Singapore Summit! this August.

title: Consulting, Web3 and Open Source, best practice to build efficiently
description:
Redwan leads the consulting project department of 120 people, multichain R&D and development company (ChainSafe).
As the Web3 industry grows, more and more third party will be involved to support the builder.
Redwan will share what are the best practice he identified from the traditional consulting world and how adapting to Web3 those can support the industry delivery quality.

speakers.name: terence tsao
speakers.description: üëã Hi, I'm a core dev at Prismatic labs. I'm most known for my work on Prysm, a consensus layer client written in Go. I mostly worked on the proof of stake Ethereum, known as the beacon chain. Lately, I've been working extensively on "the merge", hybrid PBS, and eip4844.

title: Hybrid PBS from CL's perspective
description:
The talk seeks to address the following questions:

- Why does PBS matter from CL's point of view? What happens if we completely ignore it on the protocol layer? What if we wait to release it?
- How did we implement hybrid PBS on CL clients from history to functional products?
- What do they look like in code?
- What are the gotchas and the trade-offs?
- What are the remaining questions we shall seek before moving to full PBS?

speakers.name: Josh Riddell
speakers.description: With 15 years of experience in cross-border banking and financial services, Josh has a deep knowledge of the regulatory landscape in TradFi, as Director of Business Risk for the Latin America Division of UBS. He started investing in crypto in 2018 and joined DeFi startup Hightop in 2021, as their Director of Compliance. Josh holds a degrees in Economics and Spanish, From the University of Utah and an MBA from USC Marshall School of Business.

title: ZKP for KYC: How Ethereum Blockchain Can Replace Traditional KYC
description: Exploring ways that we can replace the traditional KYC program with a ZKP option in the future, in a way that is compliant for global financial regulators and more secure for platforms and users alike.

speakers.name: Ariah Klages-Mundt
speakers.description: Ariah is a DeFi researcher with a track record of predicting design problems in stablecoins, including the design issues in Dai that contributed to Black Thursday. He has designed and built a large part of Gyroscope, including new AMMs and stablecoin markets. He is an Applied Math PhD student at Cornell University, for which he was a Bloomberg Fellow and Commercialization Fellow. He worked previously in the financial technology sector.

speakers.name: Steffen Schuldenzucker
speakers.description: I study and design AMMs, stablecoin markets, and other cryptoeconomic systems. I've co-designed a large part of Gyroscope's core system. In my academic research, I have studied the stability of financial systems using game theory and network theory. Previously PostDoc at Goethe University. CS PhD from University of Zurich.

title: Designing Autonomous Markets for Stablecoin Monetary Policy
description: We discuss the design of primary (i.e., minting and redemption) market mechanisms for non-custodial stablecoins. We first introduce a new analytical tool, the *redemption curve*, which represents the redemption price as a function of redemption pressure. We use it to discuss historical de-peggings (e.g. in DAI, UST). We then describe a new dynamic redemption curve with desirable robustness properties and show how to implement a primary market based on this curve. The system is part of Gyroscope.

speakers.name: Jenni Nguyen
speakers.description: Operations, ConsenSys Academy

title: The Future of Education is Web3
description:
Education has changed with each iteration of the web and the most explosive iteration of education is yet to be discovered through web3.

A 2017 report from UNESCO announced about 6 out of 10 children and adolescents worldwide are not achieving minimum proficiency levels in reading and mathematics, signaling ‚Äúa learning crisis‚Äù that could threaten progress on global development goals.

Web3 has the power to change this narrative. How do we do it?

speakers.name: Raphael Mazet
speakers.description: Rapha√´l is the co-founder and CEO of SimpleFi, a data analytics platform for DeFi (Decentralized Finance). He has founded several blockchain-based social impact and DeFi protocols since 2016, including Alice.si. Rapha√´l is former lobbyist, a French-British british coder and currently lives in sunny Lisbon.

speakers.name: Tarun Bansal
speakers.description: Fullstack developer with 10+ years experience developing products from scratch for startups

title: The pain of indexing DeFi positions, and how to solve it

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description: Indexing account positions in DeFi is a nightmare. The ERC20 standard is powerless against things like the lack or events emitted by pools and vaults, transfers to the zero address and many more weird DeFi quirks. This horror show makes it very difficult to track actual returns. As a result, users end up relying on bullshit, easily-gamed metrics like APYs displayed on protocol UIs to make decisions. Join us as we expose the rot and propose new token/contract standards to make DeFi great again.

speakers.name: Rikard Hjort
speakers.description: Rikard Hjort is researching formal methods for developing high-assurance smart contracts for blockchains. He worked on formalizing WebAssembly in K, and now uses KWasm to verify smart contracts written in WebAssembly. He has an M.Sc. in Computer Science from the Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden. He was an intern at Google in 2016 and 2017, and studied at the University of Tokyo in 2017-2018 where he combined his research on blockchains with studying coercion-resistant voting protocols.

title: Formal methods for the working DeFi dev
description: Runtime Verification is known for formal methods, but you don't need a PhD to make your code better by thinking like a prover. Here we want to show you how you as a developer or auditor can apply fairly simple mathematical thinking to make your code more robust and your security work simpler. By thinking ‚Äúinvariants first‚Äù you can get stronger tests, better docs, and reduce the risk of introducing bugs in your future coding.

speakers.name: Jonathan Wu
speakers.description: Jon is the Head of Growth at Aztec, the privacy layer for web3.

title: Privacy: why now?
description:
A talk on privacy on blockchain and its use cases.

The case for privacy as discretion, privacy as security, and privacy as a creative force for novel applications.

speakers.name: Josie Lauritsen
speakers.description: Josie Lauritsen is VP of Social Impact at Hightop, a consumer banking alternative powered by web3/DeFi. She holds a PhD from Cornell University, where her award-winning work focused on international development. She has led global philanthropic campaigns and worked with communities and organizations around the world to build grassroots social change initiatives. Josie is passionate about helping blockchain technologists use their skills/expertise to solve pressing global problems.

title: Farming for Farmers
description: More than half of the people living in extreme poverty around the world are smallholder farmers. What if yield farming could increase farmers' yields and help end global poverty? This Devcon we‚Äôre launching the Farming for Farmers movement in partnership with One Acre Fund‚Äîthe world‚Äôs most respected nonprofit supporting smallholder farmers. Join us to learn how you can take part.

speakers.name: Charlie Andrews-Jubelt
speakers.description: Charlie is a Software Engineering Team Lead at Valora, a non-custodial wallet app on Celo, and a cofounder of Revo, a yield farming dapp. He is from Los Angeles, studied at MIT and currently lives in San Francisco. Charlie has led his team‚Äôs effort to develop and integrate with the FiatConnect specification, and grow it into a community-led effort. His fun fact is he was Rookie of the Year on American Ninja Warrior Season 9 (#glorydays).

title: FiatConnect: a Universal API Specification for Cash-in/Cash-out on the Blockchain
description: FiatConnect is a standardized API specification and SDK that will significantly reduce the engineering costs of integrations between wallets and fiat-to-crypto liquidity providers. With a single, low-friction implementation, wallets will gain access to all FiatConnect-compliant liquidity providers in all geos. By implementing a FiatConnect API (or wrapper around their existing API), liquidity providers will be able to integrate with new wallets with no bespoke integration effort.

speakers.name: Tyrone Lobban
speakers.description: Tyrone leads J.P. Morgan‚Äôs Blockchain & Crypto team and is responsible for creating innovative Web3-focused products & solutions for J.P. Morgan‚Äôs businesses and clients, and for engaging with the industry at large in order to provide a holistic blockchain strategy for the firm. Tyrone is also the Head of Onyx Digital Assets, a multi-asset tokenization platform that enables the exchange of value for various types of digital assets. Tyrone was previously Head of Product for Quorum, an open-source

title: Decentralized Identity - avoiding dystopia and maximizing data portability in web3
description: The world of web3 centers around asset and data ownership, however if not done carefully can lead to an even more dystopian world than web2. We explore various models of decentralized identity from NFTs to SBTs to Verifiable Credentials, and discuss fundamental pillars of privacy and portability.

speakers.name: Everton Fraga
speakers.description:
Former Software Engineer at the Ethereum Foundation, now working for AWS as Sr. Blockchain Specialist. 

Purpose-driven builder, helping a variety of blockchain businesses being built on the cloud.

title: How AWS is helping the Web3 ecosystem worldwide
description: Web3 is the most fascinating movement of our time, that is for sure. Come and check the multiple ways AWS has been helping web3 startups across the globe. Hint: it goes beyond cloud infrastructure!

speakers.name: Marek Olszewski
speakers.description: Marek is the co-founder and CTO of cLabs, one of the companies contributing to Celo, and President of Valora, an easy-to-use mobile wallet built on Celo. Earlier, he co-founded Locu, a machine learning venture-backed company that was acquired by GoDaddy. He is also an MIT PhD alumni and a former Facebook Fellow and has previously worked at Google, Microsoft Research, and Sun Labs.

title: Adding Narwhal and Move support to the Celo client
description: Mysten Labs and cLabs are working on a number of upgrades to the Celo client that will lead to both big scalability improvements and the ability for developers to write and deploy smart contracts in both Solidity and Move. This talk will cover the experience of integrating Narwhal and a second VM into an existing geth-based blockchain client.

speakers.name: Joshua Tan
speakers.description: Executive director of Metagov, mathematician and computer scientist at Oxford and Stanford. See joshuatan.com/research

title: The building blocks of politics
description: Governance begets politics, which concerns the governance of governance. But there are many more modes of politics than the familiar forms of electoral and interest-group politics, just as there are many more modes of governance than the law. In this talk, I describe the matrix of relationships between politics and governance; discuss modular, computational, and linear political modalities; and introduce the Validator Commons, the world‚Äôs first cryptopolitical party.

speakers.name: Tina Haibodi
speakers.description: Head of Design at Element Finance

title: Designing in Defi: Reinventing Trading Interfaces for Fixed and Variable Markets

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description:
The notion of this talk is to reflect on the design patterns that were created historically and why we should work to iterate on them: 

1) Review the historical implications of Defi Summer and the trading design patterns established and how they affect protocols capital efficiency, liquidity and user behaviour
2) Designing for product market fit and how it will help on-ramp institutional and retail users more effectively
3) Using game design UI elements to enable mainstream adoption

speakers.name: Windra Thio
speakers.description: Founding team member of Element Finance. Currently Head of Strategy and lead growth initiatives. Previously led BD in capital markets specializing in digital securities.

title: Applications of Behavioral Economics into Currency Design
description: As users go through market cycles, the utility designs of digital currencies are tested and put to the test. Majority if not all underperform due to variables such as the concepts of user rationale and thinking as market cycles change not being considered.

speakers.name: David Kavazi
speakers.description: Founded and exited 2 companies in consumer IT before becoming a crypto researcher. Founder of a company that made staking UX easy. Now working on making biometrics private to create decentralised pseudonymous identities at Humanode.

title: Implementation of crypto-biometric identities
description: Achieving privacy and Sybil-resistance by applying ZKP to biometric neural networks

speakers.name: Ryan Lackey
speakers.description: Ryan Lackey has been a cypherpunk since the early 1990s. After working on anonymous Chaumian blinded electronic cash and dropping out of MIT, he moved to the Caribbean to build his first startup. Co-founder of the world's first offshore datahaven, HavenCo, he also has worked as a war-zone defense contractor, founded a YC-funded startup to Cloudflare, and is now Chief Security Officer of Evertas, the first dedicated cryptoasset insurance company.

title: Cypherpunks Checklist
description: The Cypherpunks Mailing List, started in the early 1990s, was a hotbed of discussion and innovation focused on technology to enable individual liberty and free exchange of information and payments. We will discuss some of the innovations first proposed on that list and show how p2p Internet protocols, cryptocurrencies, and Ethereum projects from multiple teams are the current realizations of those ideas.

speakers.name: CJ Hetherington
speakers.description:
CJ is a Web3 startup founder operator that built one of the first ever DeFi NFT games on Ethereum and is now building the Web3 social metaverse at Atlantis World. CJ also engages in various other DAO, advisory and speaking ops around the world including at Unchain Fund and speaking engagements in Davos during the WEF Annual Meeting.
https://twitter.com/cjhtech 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lB-QGODjWnM 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YDhk6iouCsQ&t=86s 
https://www.linkedin.com/in/cjhweb3/

speakers.name: Steph Orpilla
speakers.description: Steph Orpilla is a Developer Relations Engineer at Polygon. She started building in the web3 space in 2020 after getting bored of big tech, and has won 6 Web3 hackathons building projects in the web3 infrastructure, DAO tooling, and public goods spaces.

title: The Impact Is The Way- How the rails of the new web must become the internet of impact, fueling the dawn of new societal regeneration together with cryptoeconomic community coordination.
description:
The talk provides a glimpse into some of the most notable Web3 fueled impact efforts from 2 serial boots on the ground social good hacktivists: CJ Hetherington and Steph Orpilla.

CJ has been involved in fundraising for aid in Ukraine at Unchain Fund (received a $2.5M donation from Vitalik) as well as ChoiceDAO. 
Steph is a DevRel Engineer at Polygon and also a co-lead for hackathons at Blu3 DAO, an org that empowers women to learn, earn and play by creating sustainable Web3 products.

speakers.name: Alim Khamisa
speakers.description: Alim is a Product Manager at Element Finance. In 2019, he co-founded the DeFi Toronto meetup which has grown to over 1,800 members worldwide. In 2017, he helped to launch one of Canada's first industrial-scale crypto-mining companies. On the academic front, he teaches part-time as an Adjunct Professor in the Blockchain Development Program at George Brown College. He recently authored a chapter titled 'Token Economies' in The Emerald Handbook of Blockchain for Business (published March 2021).

title: A Framework for New Product Development in Web3
description:
I‚Äôll cover frameworks and useful tools to help emerging web3 product development teams:‚Ä®
1. have a structured approach to identifying problem-solution fit‚Ä®
2. properly sequence activities including requirements analysis and mapping data flows (smart contracts highly influence UX)‚Ä® 
3. know when to engage dev teams (SC, FE, data eng) throughout the process  
4. understand common web3 nuances that affect UX, specifically entry and exit points (vs. web2)

speakers.name: Theo Diamandis
speakers.description: Researcher at Bain Capital Crypto & MIT PhD student

title: A Mechanism for Pricing Non-fungible Resources: Toward Multi-dimensional Fee Markets
description: We propose a new mechanism for multi-dimensional resource pricing in blockchains. Currently, many blockchain systems operate with either fixed transaction fees or fixed relative prices of different resources (e.g., compute, memory, storage). Our proposed mechanism prices resources independently and automatically in a way that maximizes some utility set by the protocol designer.

speakers.name: Ryan Lackey
speakers.description: Ryan Lackey has been a cypherpunk since the early 1990s. After working on anonymous Chaumian blinded electronic cash and dropping out of MIT, he moved to the Caribbean to build his first startup. Co-founder of the world's first offshore datahaven, HavenCo, he also has worked as a war-zone defense contractor, founded a YC-funded startup to Cloudflare, and is now Chief Security Officer of Evertas, the first dedicated cryptoasset insurance company.

title: How to not be worth kidnapping

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description: Personal physical security, specifically violent kidnapping and compulsion to disclose keys, is often brought up as a concern by cryptocurrency participants. We will quickly present a way of thinking about these threats and a model for not merely protecting from loss of cryptocurrency, but prevention of victimization through violence entirely.

speakers.name: Andrei Vacaru
speakers.description: Andrei VƒÉcaru works out of RV‚Äôs Bucharest based subsidiary. In addition to his full time position at RV, Andrei is pursuing a Master degree at the University of Bucharest in Security and Applied Logic. Andrei developed a keen interest in functional programming and formal methods after developing a Haskell based interpreter for an imperative language.

title: Integrating the SMTChecker into your contract development workflow
description: Full formal verification, though desirable, is very difficult to achieve for all smart contracts; but this does not mean we have to give up on more rigorous development entirely. There are many techniques and tools that developers can leverage besides full formal verification which boost confidence and safety throughout the development lifecycle. In this talk, we‚Äôll demonstrate how to use the Solidity SMTChecker to do lightweight verification while developing your smart contracts.

speakers.name: Juan Bautista Carpanelli
speakers.description: I'm a  senior software engineer and security researcher at OpenZeppelin. I've been working in the crypto space for the last 4 years, leading audits of top companies in the ecosystem such as AAVE, Compound, and The Graph. I have experience giving talks in public, including past Devcon events.

title: Incident Response at OpenZeppelin
description:
At OpenZeppelin we have been defining processes to help protocols act quickly if an emergency is detected on-chain. The goal of this talk is to walk through the steps that any team should follow - from the detection of an anomaly that can lead to an incident, to:
Manual and automatic pausing, transaction analysis, bug-fix audit and deployment, internal communication in war rooms, external communication to stakeholders, and much more.

-

speakers.name: Theo Diamandis
speakers.description: Researcher at Bain Capital Crypto & MIT PhD student

title: Efficient Routing across DEXs
description: Most DEXs are implemented as constant function market makers (CFMMs), a class of automated market maker whose behavior is governed by a function of its reserves. We will survey the mathematical properties of CFMMs through the lens of convex analysis. Then, we will show that executing a trade optimally across a network of CFMMs (the routing problem) is a convex optimization problem. Finally, we will present an efficient algorithm and its open source implementation.

speakers.name: Victoria
speakers.description: I have been working with StableNode since June last year, and I am today handling the product development of the team. I come from a traditional consulting background, but jumped in with both feet in crypto, NFT's and DAO's.

title: Findings in DAO's for a PM
description: As a PM for a governance focused product I will in this lightning talk go over some of my curious findings upon doing more research into DAO's. I will talk about some of the interesting facts I have encountered in my journey starting as a beginner to today.

speakers.name: Sandra Ro
speakers.description: Sandra is a proponent for ‚Äòhuman-centric tech‚Äô. From investment banking to blockchain technology, she is an early investor of crypto and digital assets. Sandra is CEO of the Global Blockchain Business Council, a leading Swiss-based not-for-profit association. She serves as Board Director of various private and public sector institutions.

title: Implementing Frameworks and Adopting Taxonomies to Advance Tokenization
description: Sandra Ro, CEO of Global Blockchain Business Council, the world's largest blockchain association, will discuss the importance of frameworks and taxonomies in advancing token-based projects. She will draw on the experience of creating and implementing the Token Taxonomy Framework (TTF), a framework designed to enable multiple parties to define a common language, behaviors, and properties for tokens. Ethereum developers can use the standards created by the TTF as a framework for creating tokens.

speakers.name: Andrei Vacaru
speakers.description: Andrei VƒÉcaru works out of RV‚Äôs Bucharest based subsidiary. In addition to his full time position at RV, Andrei is pursuing a Master degree at the University of Bucharest in Security and Applied Logic. Andrei developed a keen interest in functional programming and formal methods after developing a Haskell based interpreter for an imperative language.

title: The Devil we Know: Re-entrancy
description: Ever since the major DAO attack, re-entrancy has plagued smart-contract developers. Attackers have found the weirdest of loopholes in contracts by exploiting this behavior in smart contracts. In this talk, we‚Äôll discuss (i) what re-entrancy is, (ii) how to identify re-entrancy in code-bases, and (iii) proper mitigation strategies against re-entrancy. Leaving this workshop, we hope you feel empowered to do your own re-entrancy analysis and keep your code safe from these pitfalls.

speakers.name: Marek Olszewski
speakers.description: Marek is the co-founder and CTO of cLabs, one of the companies contributing to Celo, and President of Valora, an easy-to-use mobile wallet built on Celo. Earlier, he co-founded Locu, a machine learning venture-backed company that was acquired by GoDaddy. He is also an MIT PhD alumni and a former Facebook Fellow and has previously worked at Google, Microsoft Research, and Sun Labs.

title: Deploying Plumo to Production ‚Äì A SNARK-based light client
description: Plumo is a SNARK-based light client protocol that lets resource constrained devices sync with a blockchain using 1KB SNARK proofs. Plumo has been under active development for 3 years and has finally launched on Celo. This talk will cover various aspects of the launch including the massive Powers of Tau ceremony required to construct the common reference string used by protocol. It will end with a demo of a web dapp that uses a WASM-verifier to trustlessly sync without using a tursted rpc node.

speakers.name: Anna Kryukova
speakers.description: Anna currently leads Community Programs at the Celo Foundation. She has previously decentralized her own job as a community lead at the Maker Foundation and is an active member of communities of care like Meta Gamma Delta Kernel. Is likely traveling and wandering around.

title: Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling: How Do We Fund Community And Ecosystem Growth
description: "Institutions are functional when they promote a delicate balance between what people can do for themselves and what tools at the service of anonymous institutions can do for them," Illich writes in Tools for Conviviality. Governance is one tool that helps with resource allocation towards what we want to see more of, at the protocol level and at the social level. Let's explore different ways of funding ecosystem and community growth including grants, on-chain funding, and new mechanisms.

speakers.name: Kayvon Tehranian
speakers.description: Kayvon Tehranian is the CEO and founder of Foundation, a platform that enables creators to use blockchain to monetize their work and build new connections with collectors.

title: The post-platform era of the internet
description:
We are entering the post-platform era of the internet. In web2, platforms like Instagram, Twitter, and Facebook centralized our data, information, and value within their walled gardens. web3 has different rules. 

This discussion will cover the evolution of NFTs and how web3 is introducing the next generation of online experiences‚Äîone where your digital objects belong to you, where you can have true ownership and sovereignty over your digital identity and belongings.

speakers.name: Josh Crites
speakers.description: I am a self taught blockchain developer who loves nurturing the infinite garden. I am energized by learning about cutting edge technology and sharing my knowledge to get others excited as well. In previous lives I was a ski patroller, a barista, a skateboard manufacturer, a farmer, a carnivorous plant researcher, among other things. :)

title: Approaches to L2 ecosystem building

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description: The battle to be the dominant L2 on Ethereum is in full swing. Building EVM-compatible L2s on Ethereum has been the dominant strategy we‚Äôve seen from projects like Optimism, Arbitrum and zkSync, but there are other projects building very different designs with different tradeoffs (Loopring, Starknet, Aztec to name a few). What are these tradeoffs? What are the implications for building an ecosystem on these networks? And what does the future look like for each?

speakers.name: Miles
speakers.description: Creator, CEO, CTO at https://trustless.fi

title: Defi is not Decentralized: Correcting the Course

room.name: Main Stage - On Top of the Mountain - 5th Floor

description: The dangerous trend of centralization in the Ethereum ecosystem risks Ethereum‚Äôs opportunity to be a refuge for excluded and oppressed people all around the globe. Luckily there are only a few small changes to how we build to ensure Ethereum has global impact for generations to come.

speakers.name: Everton Fraga
speakers.description:
Former Software Engineer at the Ethereum Foundation, now working for AWS as Sr. Blockchain Specialist. 

Purpose-driven builder, helping a variety of blockchain businesses being built on the cloud.

speakers.name: David Dornseifer
speakers.description:
David Dornseifer is a Blockchain Architect with the Amazon ProServe Blockchain team. 
He focuses on helping customers design, deploy and scale end-to-end Blockchain solutions in production on AWS.

title: Security best practices to store keys and sign transactions at scale on the cloud
description:
Since the last Devcon, the Ethereum ecosystem bloomed. Thousands of startups are now building on top of Ethereum constructs. Security should always be the top priority. Especially for a multi-blockchain world, that puts security pressure on the trusted operators.

Come learn best practices from AWS experts on how to leverage (affordable) highest security standards for the cloud. AWS Key Management Service, AWS CloudHSM, data protection, threat detection.

speakers.name: Eric Nakagawa
speakers.description:
Currently: leading developer relations team at Celo
Previously: literal memelord

speakers.name: Ernest Nnamdi
speakers.description: I am software developer passionate about building products that have impact on the lives of everyday people.

speakers.name: Harpalsinh Jadeja
speakers.description: DevRel @CeloOrg

speakers.name: Viral
speakers.description: Software Developer | Web3 | Flutter | JS | DevRel @celoOrg

title: Building Mobile DeFi dApps / Building Better Mobile web3 dApps
description:
Problem: Dapp developers are still focused on desktop user experiences.

Solution: A workshop that covers best practices for building amazing mobile defi dapp experiences (for native and mobile web). This includes: UX and UI design tips (colors), mobile design tips, usability design for non-English/Western users, tips for displaying complex financial information (graphs), and thoughtful defaults.

I have spoken to over 10k developers in 15 countries about mobile app development.

speakers.name: Evin McMullen
speakers.description: Evin McMullen is CEO and Co-founder of Disco, your identity for the Metaverse. Disco makes data and reputation portable across web2 and the web3 blockchain ecosystem, with the same keys you use on-chain. She is a member of DAO Jones, Boys Club and inkDAO and an advisor to Web3 projects including Engage Raise and DoomsdayX. She is a graduate of Yale University.

title: Data Backpacks for the Multichain Metaverse
description: Wallets taught us to own tokens. Now it's time to level up beyond the chain. Data backpacks let us carry the rest of our stuff on adventures from one app to the next, across web2 and web3 chains. The world of fun unlocked with our keys is waiting, and financial use cases are only the start of what's possible. From parties to memberships, explore the magic of verifiable, off-chain credentials, cross-chain interop without bridges or gas fees.

speakers.name: Jackie Bona
speakers.description: Jackie Bona is the CEO of Valora, a mobile-first crypto wallet whose mission is to unlock access to financial opportunity for people around the world. Prior to working in crypto, Jackie spent 15 years launching products in emerging markets for companies such as Spotify, Twitter, & Google. She is passionate about financial inclusion, & believes that blockchain technology has the potential to provide new economic opportunities to those who would not typically have access.

title: From HODL to mobile: putting crypto to work, unlocking use cases via mobile
description: Research shows crypto usage is still dominated by HODLers, with 39% of people keeping hold of their crypto assets instead of putting them to work. From everyday commerce to unlocking earning potential through dApps, there are so many opportunities to use crypto in new ways that simply aren‚Äôt possible with TradFi. This panel features innovators that have used DeFi to offer new pathways to financial empowerment for communities in emerging markets, sharing learnings from today & what's next.

speakers.name: Colfax Selby
speakers.description: Colfax is the co-founder & CEO of GitPOAP, a decentralized professional reputation platform.  He has a passion for open source software and the empowerment that can come through decentralization.

title: Implementing professional identity on chain for our Decentralized Society
description: I'll provide an overview of what our future Decentralized Society (DeSoc) may look like & what it enables (building off of the paper "Decentralized Society: Finding Web3's Soul" by Weyl, Ohlhaver, & Buterin and my work as the founder & CEO of GitPOAP.io).  Specifically, I'll then focus on how we can effectively build decentralized professional reputations and what DeSoc unlocks for contributors & projects such as self-sovereign reputation, governance, goods funding, and coordination.

speakers.name: Fernando Boiero
speakers.description: MBA, Systems Engineer certified as Project Manager by PMI. Cyber Security Specialist with 20 years of technological market experience and 13 years managing cybersecurity, blockchain and Artificial intelligence projects.

speakers.name: Maximiliano Cesar Nivoli
speakers.description:
I have more than 13 years of experience in software development.
I worked with several programming languages such as C, C++, JAVA, PHP, Javascript, TypeScript and Python, although in the last years I have been working with Javascript, PHP, TypeScript, Python and Solidity.

I love open source software and whenever time allows me I try to collaborate with the community in some way.
I love challenges and teamwork!.

I'm currently a Programmer and Technical Lead at Xcapit.

title: Building open-source products is the way forward
description:
Open source is the key factor of the fast and solid development of the blockchain. It allows for open collaboration, decentralized verification and community building. 
Bitcoin and Ethereum wouldn't have become what they are today, if they had not been open source.
In this talk, we will walk through our experience, accompanied by UNICEF, which made us transition from a private to an open source model. The benefits, the struggles, and what's more, the reward of being recognized as a DPG.

speakers.name: Kaushal
speakers.description: Kaushal is a contributor at Status Network and focuses on ecosystem development for the Nimbus Client. He works with staking services, staking infrastructure operators, liquid staking protocols, solo staking community members and centralized exchanges to promote use of minority clients and improve client diversity in the network. In this capacity, he has gained deep insights about the motivations and challenges of various personas in the validator ecosystem.

title: Validating made light and simple
description:
The network has seen an increase in staked Eth led by staking pools, liquid staking protocols, CEX and solo stakers. The complexity of running multiple clients (Execution, Consensus, Beacon and possibly MEV) means that validating is increasingly considered an organised activity for teams of specialists. 
Nimbus is pushing for simplification to ensure it remains accessible to individuals and institutions alike. In this talk, Nimbus presents its vision for the future of Ethereum client experience

speakers.name: Amanda Cassatt
speakers.description: Amanda Cassatt is a notable product builder who brought Ethereum to market as the former CMO of ConsenSys, supporting its growth to become the largest and most robust blockchain ecosystem. Amanda is the CEO and founder of Serotonin, the largest web3 product studio & marketing firm for transformative technologies. She is also the founder and president of Mojito, the premier web3 platform for NFT commerce and community that spun out of Serotonin in 2021. Mojito powers Sotheby‚Äôs Metaverse.

title: Decentralization and designing self-marketing systems
description: Building on Serotonin founder and former ConsenSys CMO Amanda Cassatt's experience contributing to bottom-up, grassroots-style community marketing best practices for Ethereum and its early products, this session will teach the founders of decentralized projects how to design systems at the crypto-economic level to grow and scale communities while fostering unique voices and sets of values.

speakers.name: Steph Orpilla
speakers.description: Steph Orpilla is a Developer Relations Engineer at Polygon. She started building in the web3 space in 2020 after getting bored of big tech, and has won 6 Web3 hackathons building projects in the web3 infrastructure, DAO tooling, and public goods spaces.

title: Building and scaling a real time dapp on Polygon
description: Ethereum transactions are secure but slow. Polygon PoS is an Ethereum scaling solution that achieves unprecedented transaction speed and cost savings by utilizing side-chains for transaction processing. Code along to build a real time dapp that showcases the power of L2s without sacrificing the security and transparency benefits of building on chain.

speakers.name: Marysol Mauricio
speakers.description: Marysol Mauricio majored in International Business. She is a blockchain consultant and is an education mentor of women on web3. She also co-runs crypto Epic Queen a community to welcome women as creators of crypto and web3. In addition, she is governor in Blu3 LATAM DAO, the mission is empowering women, non-binary and trans people to learn, explore and build their careers and visions in the web3 space.

speakers.name: ANA KAREN  RAMIREZ TELLEZ
speakers.description: MIT INNOVATOR UNDER 35. She is the founder and CEO in Epic Queen, a EDTECH Startup  that seeks to close the gender gap in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths) by giving EDUCATION to more than 80 thousand  girls and women. In 2018, Epic Queen was named as one of the 100 initiatives of digital social innovation that are transforming Latin America. In Ana Karen is Crypto Queens Founder, where they educate women in crypto with an NFT project to give crypto scholarships

title: Buy, Sell & Create NFTs
description:
This course is designed to introduce you to the NFTs , we will explore the basic fundamentals of them to understand what it is, and how the technology behind them arises and the current and future impact on various industries. Anybody can create an NFT, but there are some important steps, and you need to understand the technologies behind it, its features and constraints.

We will guide step by step and show how easy it is to buy, sell and create an NFT.

speakers.name: Ryan Lackey
speakers.description: Ryan Lackey has been a cypherpunk since the early 1990s. After working on anonymous Chaumian blinded electronic cash and dropping out of MIT, he moved to the Caribbean to build his first startup. Co-founder of the world's first offshore datahaven, HavenCo, he also has worked as a war-zone defense contractor, founded a YC-funded startup to Cloudflare, and is now Chief Security Officer of Evertas, the first dedicated cryptoasset insurance company.

title: How to make cryptocurrency less appealing for ransomware
description: Unfortunately, ransomware and other forms of cybercrime are often the first introduction some users have to cryptocurrency -- having to learn about the ecosystem quickly to get some funds to pay a criminal to unlock their files and get back to work.  We will discuss some ways cryptocurrency can be made less desirable as a way of facilitating those payments while preserving privacy and censorship resistance generally.

speakers.name: Shumo Chu
speakers.description: I am co-founder of Manta Network. I graduated as a PhD from University of Washington Computer Science and Engineering, where I was advised by computer scientist Dan Suciu. I obtained my bachelor degree from Wuhan University, China. Before Manta, I was a research scientist at Algorand and assistant professor at UCSB.

title: The future of composable privacy solutions on EVM
description:
We propose a forum of a technical discussions of composable EVM privacy solutions, their design trade-offs, their technical assumptions, and the way they can help developing future dApps with privacy guarantee. Below is the list of project we are planning to invite:

1. Manta Network
2. Espresso Systems
3. Aztec 
4. Tornado.cash

speakers.name: Tomasz Kornuta
speakers.description:
I am an applied research scientist, able to drive research into novel directions.

With over 20 years in academia and industry, I have developed strong analytical & problem solving skills along with deep expertise in software engineering, robotics, visual perception and machine learning.

I am a fan of robotics, AI, design patterns and MOOCs.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Query Pricing in The Graph
description: Indexers‚Äã‚Äã in The Graph protocol use a DSL called Agora‚Äã to map query shapes to prices. However, manually populating and updating Agora models for each query is a tedious task, and, as a consequence, most indexers default to a flat pricing model. We have created and deployed reinforcement learning agents for Indexers to automatically compete on pricing. This talk will focus on our development process and our study of the market effects of multiple competing pricing agents.

speakers.name: Ian Miers
speakers.description: Ian Miers is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at the University of Maryland. His research focuses on solving real world security issues using cryptography. He is one of the cofounders of Aleo, Bolt Labs, and Zcash, startups commercializing his work on privacy preserving payments and smart contracts. His work has been featured in The Washington Post, The New York Times, Wired, and The Economist. It has also been denounced in at least two op-eds.

title: Scalability is boring, privacy is dead: zk-proofs, what are they good for?
description: The first mainstream uses of zero-knowledge(zk) proofs were for private payments in systems like Zcash and then scalability. In both, we hide data to improve privacy or validation costs. But private payments, unfortunately, have seen limited direct demand. And scalability needs faster proofs but not even zero-knowledge. What are practical zk proofs good for? This talk considers zk proofs + blockchains as a tool both for cryptocurrency and broader applications.

speakers.name: Sebastian Serrano
speakers.description: Sebasti√°n is an Argentine Endeavor Entrepreneur and one of the leading global experts in Blockchain technology and cryptocurrencies. In 2007 he founded a software development company that provides solutions to various startups in the region. Around 2012 he immersed himself in the world of cryptocurrencies. In 2013 he created Ripio, one of the fastest growing crypto companies in Latin America with more than 3 million users, which was selected by the WEF as one of the 2020 Tech Pioneers.

title: Emergent Web3: what Latin America can teach the world about building the Internet‚Äôs future
description: Driven by both a wealth of human talent and a historical need for better monetary and financial systems, Latin America has consistently been at the forefront of Web3 innovation. This panel will discuss the experiences that brought the regional ecosystem to its current state and provide insights into some of its most prominent projects, including Kleros and Proof of Humanity.

speakers.name: Alexander Attar
speakers.description: Alexander has been working in the blockchain space since 2014, originally motivated by Bitcoin and it's promise. In 2016 he fell down the Ethereum rabbit hole and never looked back.
